text:
(1)

217 Fulton Street (right, "El" thereon), at the S. E. corner of Concord Street, showing the Brooklyn Savings Bank of the 1800's, the building extending east to Liberty Street and bearing number 62 on the latter. The bank purchased the building in 1846 and rebuilt it in the 1880's. It was sold in 1908 and a new bank structure erected at Pierpont and Clinton Streets. Peter's Tavern later came to occupy the building.

1922

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

(2)

The old bank building, being used as Peter's Tavern.

June 2, 1931

P. L. Sperr

(3)

The Liberty Street side of the building, here three stories high and bearing number 62. The building was later demolished, as were many others in this area, to make way for a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

October 4, 1935

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1) Fulton Street, at the N.W. corner of Pineapple Street, showing the building in which the Universalist Church met prior to removal to its present location. It is also claimed that this building, in 1802, was leased by a religious organization, known as the Winchester Association. On the opposite corner partially seen, was the Fulton Market in 1856. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, showing more of the market. Also seen is the Fulton Street Elevated Line of the B.M.T. April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster collection.

(1) Fulton Street, at the N.W. corner of Pineapple Street, showing the building in which the Universalist Church met prior to removal to its present location. It is also claimed that this building, in 1802, was leased by a religious organization, known as the Winchester Association. On the opposite corner partially seen, was the Fulton Market in 1856. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, showing more of the market. Also seen is the Fulton Street Elevated Line of the B.M.T. April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster collection.

Pineapple Street, at the N.W. corner of Fulton Street. Site of the Brooklyn Opera House, destroyed by fire in 1848. In the background is the Fulton Elevated Lines.

1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Concord Street, north side, between Fulton and Liberty Streets, showing what in 1856, was the Fulton Market. At the left, (overhead), is part of the Fulton Street Elevated Line.

1928.

Eugene L. Armbruster collection.

(2)
The Same, from a different angle.

1928.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Concord Street, north side, between Fulton and Liberty Streets, showing what in 1856, was the Fulton Market. At the left, (overhead), is part of the Fulton Street Elevated Line.

1928.

Eugene L. Armbruster collection.

(2)
The Same, from a different angle.

1928.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Fulton Street (elevated thereon), east side, north from near Tillary Street, showing W. P. A. laborers demolishing all the buildings on the east side of Fulton Street as well as those on Liberty Street (right) to make way for the construction of a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. View 1 shows Fulton Street extending north to Concord Street and view 2 shows the area north from Concord to Nassau Streets. In the lower right hand corner, at the S. E. corner of Concord Street, is Peter's Tavern, formerly the Brooklyn Savings Bank. The building is about a century old. The buildings seen in view 2 will also be demolished.

March, 1936
Views 1,2

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

Fulton Street (elevated thereon), east side, north from near Tillary Street, showing W. P. A. laborers demolishing all the buildings on the east side of Fulton Street as well as those on Liberty Street (right) to make way for the construction of a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. View 1 shows Fulton Street extending north to Concord Street and view 2 shows the area north from Concord to Nassau Streets. In the lower right hand corner, at the S. E. corner of Concord Street, is Peter's Tavern, formerly the Brooklyn Savings Bank. The building is about a century old. The buildings seen in view 2 will also be demolished.

March, 1936
Views 1,2

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

Fulton Street, west side, between Pineapple (left) and Middagh (right) Streets, across clearing from Liberty Street. The foreground will be part of a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. Also shown is the Fulton Street Elevated Lines.

April 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
